NUCLEAR BOMBS AND ROCKET SITES IN SINGAPORE
(Statement by the Prime Minister)


    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have no knowledge of any information as to storing of nuclear bombs and the erection of rocket sites within the State of Singapore. As Members are aware, defence and external affairs are matters reserved to the British Government under our Constitution, and so it will continue to be if the Communists' anti-colonial struggle through the Barisan Sosialis for full internal self-government without the Internal Security Council were to be accepted by this House. However, after merger, defence and external affairs will be in the hands of the Government of the Federation of Malaysia, and the elected government of the people of Malaysia can decide what is in the best defence interests of Malaysia.

STATUS OF NANYANG UNIVERSITY AND ITS RELATIONSHIP
WITH GOVERNMENT
(Statement by the Minister for Education)


    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the White Paper on Merger setting out the Heads of Agreement between the Federation of Malaya and Singapore (Command Paper 33 of 1961) which was passed, without dissent, by the Legislative Assembly on 6th December, 1961, allows for local autonomy in education for Singapore, and therefore the position of Nanyang University is not in any way affected by the merger proposals.

    The Member for Anson is doubtless aware that under the Barisan Sosialis proposal for the so-called "complete

Column: 831

merger", which he supports, the Singapore Government must treat Nanyang University in the same manner as the Federation Government does. If education is not a subject of local autonomy, there will be no question of recognising Nanyang University or doing anything to assist it until it conforms to the national education policy. Even the bursaries we now pay to Singapore students at Nanyang University will have to cease.

    I find it difficult to reconcile the Member for Anson's apparent concern for Nanyang University with his support for a type of merger which means Nanyang University will have to comply with the Rahman Talib Report or not to be supported at all and so upset Chinese educationists in general.

    On 31st October, 1961, in the Speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, Hansard, Vol. 15, No. 1, column 22, mention was made of Nanyang University in the following words:-

    `The Government is as anxious as the founders of Nanyang University that the University should be reorganised. Towards this end, a liaison committee comprising representatives of the Government and the University held several meetings last year to discuss ways and means of implementing the recommendations made by the Nanyang University Review Committee. Although no agreement has been reached by the liaison committee, nonetheless the Government is always ready to negotiate and discuss this matter. There are hopes that this problem will be solved in the coming year.'

    On 27th November last, at a dinner given by the Prime Minister to the President and 9 members of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce which included Mr Tan Lark Sye, discussions were held on the arrangements for local autonomy on education and labour, trade and commerce, language and citizenship. The Prime Minister then suggested to Mr Tan that there should be agreement between the present Council of Nanyang University and the Ministry of Education as soon as possible before July or August 1962 so that provisions could be included in the budget for 1963. Mr Tan Lark Sye suggested, with the other members of the Chamber of Commerce present

Column: 832

agreeing, that the matter could be left to informal discussions between a member of the Chamber present who was named, and Mr Lee Khoon Choy, my Parliamentary Secretary, who was also a Government representative in the Liaison Committee which carried out discussions with the Nanyang University Council in 1960.

    One of the outstanding matters before agreement can be reached is the question of representation in the new University Council. The Government stand is that the balance of representation in the Council would and should leave academic policy decisions with the academicians and teachers in the University, whereas the proposals of the present Nanyang University authorities meant that all policy decisions both academic and otherwise should be with the merchants who first sponsored the University.

    The Government was and is of the view that, although the public-spiritedness and interest in education of our Chinese merchants deserve praise for having helped to create Nanyang University, merchants and businessmen are not necessarily the best qualified people to decide academic and educational matters involved in the running of the University.

    The Government is prepared to discuss all details, including annual grants by the Government to Nanyang University, in accordance with the principles of the Gwee Ah Leng Review Committee's Report. In this connection, Dr Gwee Ah Leng has referred me to reports published in both the Nanyang Siang Pau and the Sin Chew Jit Poh dated 27th January, 1962, attributed to Mr Tan Lark Sye at a dinner speech of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce held at the Ee Ho Hean Club on 26th. January in which Mr Tan alleged that Dr Gwee had to amend his report three times because the Government was not satisfied with it. Dr Gwee informed me that he had written to Mr Tan Lark Sye by registered post, asking him to correct this unfounded statement. With Dr Gwee's permission, I wish to table a photostat copy of his letter in Chinese.

for information of the House. If you will permit me,

Sir, to read the English translation which goes as

follows:-



                                 27th January, 1962.



  `Chairman Tan,



  I  have read in a report in the Nanyang Siang  Pau

of   27th   instant  of  your  speech  on   Nanyang

University at the dinner in Ee Ho Hean Club.  There

is  some  misunderstanding which I  would  like  to

Column: 833

FEDERATION OF MALAYSIA


2.43 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate.

    Mr Speaker: The Original Question, as amended, was:

    "That, in pursuance of the national objective of a united Malayan nation, enlarged and strengthened by the addition of our brothers in the Borneo territories, this House declares its support in principle for the plan proposed by the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra Al-Haj, and agreed to in principle in the Federation Parliament on 18th October, 1961, for the establishment of the Federation of Malaysia, comprising the eleven States of the present Federation, the State of Singapore and Brunei, and the territories of Sarawak and North Borneo.".

Since which amendments have been proposed,

    In line 4, to leave out "plan" and insert "motion":

    In line 6, to leave out "in principle".

    The Question is, "That the word 'plan' proposed to be left out, be left out." As has been said before, the debate may range over both amendments and the Original Question, as amended.

Column: 834



2.44 p.m.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the House rose on Friday evening, I had just addressed it for about three or four minutes. Perhaps, Sir, if you will allow me to recapitulate shortly what I had mentioned to the House in a few words and then proceed from there, so that my speech might then he received in proper perspective.

    When the first motion on merger with the Federation was discussed. I got the impression, as my colleagues also did, that so far as the Barisan Sosialis were concerned, they were all for the Malaysian concept as outlined by the Tunku. In fact, the whole outcry from the Barisan Sosialis side against the Tunku, insofar as Singapore was concerned, was that Singapore was not being treated in the same way that the Borneo territories were being treated. It appeared from their side that the Tunku had offered to bring in the three Borneo territories as three additional States into the Federation on an equal footing, shall we say, with Johore or Selangor or with any other State in the Federation. They also said that if only the Tunku made all the Singapore citizens Federal citizens, they would be quite happy to go in as the twelfth State. In fact, the whole outcry against the Tunku was that Singapore would not be made the twelfth State. Now if that is the correct appreciation of the main line on which the Barisan opposed the merger proposals, I, at the moment, do not understand the line taken by them on the Malaysia motion. I believe we started to debate the motion on merger with the Federation on 17th November last year which lasted for two or three weeks. But since then, it would appear that the point of attack has changed. The point of attack now is not about the Borneo territories coming in as the twelfth, thirteenth and fourteenth States. It is that they are not being allowed to have a say in whether they should be part of Malaysia or whether they should stay out; whether or not the first step in the Malaysia proposals should not

Column: 835

be independence for each of these territories, then an understanding between the three of them, and finally their coming into the Malaysia proposals after that.

    Therefore, it seems fairly clear now - to me anyway, Mr Speaker - that there has been a change of front insofar as the Barisan Sosialis are concerned on Malaysia. I got the impression, from the first debate, that they were all for Malaysia. But that what is objectionable in the Malaysia proposals was the status that was being given to Singapore and that Singapore citizens were going to become second-class citizens. Now the point of attack is something quite different. I was listening to a number of Barisan Sosialis Members speaking in the hope that they would explain to the House why this change of attitude had taken place since the conclusion of the debate on the merger with the Federation motion and the commencement of this debate on the Malaysia motion. I think it was the Minister for Culture who suggested to the Barisan Sosialis that the change of front was because the Barisan Sosialis are not following a line of their own, and that their line is being dictated to them by forces outside Singapore and forces with which Singapore should not be concerned at all. It has since been denied by the Barisan that that is so. But the facts point to this, that during the course of the West Irian debate, the Member for Thomson said that Malaysia is an anti-Indonesian move. That idea was not mentioned during the debate on the original motion on merger with the Federation. Although Malaysia had been touched upon - not at length, of course, Mr Speaker, Sir; the principle of it had been touched upon in the first debate - there was never any suggestion by any of the speakers on the Barisan side that Malaysia was an anti-Indonesian move. Now I, for myself, fail to understand how the Barisan Sosialis

    - particularly the Member for Thomson - could have said that it was an anti-Indonesian move when my understanding of the Malaysia proposals was that it had the blessing of the Indonesian Government. I believe the

Column: 836

Foreign Minister of Indonesia has stated in no uncertain terms that insofar as the Malaysia proposals are concerned, Indonesia has no objections. Now if that is the attitude of the Indonesian Government, Mr Speaker, Sir, where then does the Member for Thomson get the idea that this is an anti-Indonesian move? It seems to me that there is something in what the Minister for Culture has been accusing the Barisan of, that this new line of the Barisan Sosialis, that this is an anti-Indonesian move, is a line which is being dictated from somebody outside Singapore and not connected with the Indonesian Government as a Government. In view of the article which appeared sometime ago in the Straits Tunes and which set out the line of the Communist Party in Indonesia, and in view of the statement made by the Member for Thomson subsequent to that, I get the impression - unless they are going to deny it with rational statement that that is not so - that they are following the line set by the Communist Party in Indonesia.

    An hon. Member: Nonsense.

    Mr Rajah: I hope for the sake of Singapore that it is nonsense. I was waiting for the Member for Thomson, when he made his speech on Friday evening, to deny that statement. You will recollect, Mr Speaker, Sir, that when the Member for Anson moved his amendment, he did call upon the Member for Thomson to give some explanation for that statement. I thought the Member for Thomson in his speech would make some reference to that and try to explain it, because I think it is important for the people of Singapore to know whether this is an anti-Indonesian move or not. If the Indonesian Government says that it is not an anti-Indonesian move, why then are the Barisan Sosialis worried about it? Surely it is the people of Singapore who elected them and not the people of Indonesia. Our main interest is to find out first whether the Malaysia proposals are something good for Singapore. After that we should consider whether it is good for the Bornean territories or whether it is good for the Federation.

Column: 837

I would have thought that, as elected representatives of the people of Singapore, our first duty was to the people of Singapore, afterwards to the Federation, and afterwards to the Borneo territories, and last of all to Indonesia. But the point of attack in the Malaysia debate seems to me that the Barisan Sosialis are more interested than the people of Singapore are in what the Communist Party in Indonesia think about the Malaysia proposals. They are open to that criticism because of the statements made by the Member for Thomson and because he has not taken the trouble to deny it or explain it in any way to this House.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to put this proposition to the Barisan Sosialis and what their attitude would be on it. Sir, the Tunku has said that he is not going to have Singapore enter the Federation unless and until the three Bornean territories come in at the same time. He has said that most categorically, and he has not departed one iota from that statement. But the Tunku has not said that if the three Borneo territories agree to go with the Federation and become part of the Federation, he will not take them without Singapore. So there is this possibility that if the Borneo territories agree to become part of the Federation as the twelfth, thirteenth and fourteenth States, and if we lost on the referendum which God forbid them - we might reach a position where the three States in Borneo become part of the Federation - if not as the twelfth, thirteenth and fourteenth States, then at least on some other arrangement with the Federation - and with Singapore staying out of this arrangement as an active opponent of the Malaysian concept. If that happened, Mr Speaker, Sir, I ask my friends in the Barisan Sosialis to think of the pretty pickle Singapore would find itself in. And if there is no merger or close understanding or anything else with the Federation as a result of a refusal on the referendum, I think that slowly but surely the pressure on Singapore will be applied and it will find itself isolated. In those circumstances, what solution

Column: 838

has the Barisan Sosialis for Singapore? Do we then say that we get the Internal Security Council away from the British and the Federation, keep internal security with the Singapore Government, and allow the British to continue to run the foreign affairs and defence of Singapore? Is that a practical possibility, Mr Speaker, Sir? Do they know whether the British will agree to that? It is all very well saying, "Let the British defend us. Let the British run our foreign affairs." But can the Barisan Sosialis give any assurance to the House that, under the conditions which I have just outlined to you, Mr Speaker, Sir, the British will continue to remain here? I do not think the British will. If the British are not going to remain here, who then are going to look after our foreign affairs and defence?

    An hon. Member: The P.K.I.

    Mr Rajah: I do not think the Indonesians want to be mixed up with us. Now where do you go from there, Mr Speaker, Sir? [Interruption] No, Mr Speaker, the whole thing is impossible. And when one analyses the arguments put forward by the Barisan Sosialis on the merger proposals with the Federation, and one applies the basis of those arguments to the arguments which they use on these Malaysia proposals, they conflict and cannot be reconciled.

    Sir, one gets the idea, therefore, that they are not being true to themselves in their arguments on this issue that is if they had been true to themselves in their arguments on the debate on the merger proposals. Now if there is this falsity of arguments on these two issues, I think one must find out what has caused this falsity of arguments. I think the Minister for Culture has a point when he urges upon the House that the reason for the difficulties in which the Barisan Sosialis find themselves at the moment is not that they are following a line of their own, but that they are following a line which someone else is setting for them. The Minister for Culture is suggesting to them that it is being sent by the Communist Party in Indonesia. Unless I hear anything further

Column: 839

on this from the Members of the Barisan Sosialis, I myself will be inclined to agree with the Minister for Culture.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, a further attack was made on the Tunku regarding the Commission that was being set up, that he was doing this without consulting the Borneo people. Sir, surely the whole point of the Commission is to ascertain the views of the people in the three territories of Borneo. I take it the Commission will sit in each of these three territories. The Prime Minister knows more about this than he would probably tell the House. But what I expect, and what would be the normal procedure, would be that the Commission goes from territory to territory ascertaining the views of the people of the Borneo territories and, on those views, they will present the Commission's Report. So I really do not understand why the Barisan Sosialis should say that the Tunku is trying to rig the Commission in order that it might give him a favourable verdict. What the Tunku has done, as I understand it, Mr Speaker, Sir, is that he has given the Bornean territories the maximum which Singapore is asking of him. Now if the Borneo territories do not want the maximum but they want something less, I feel certain the Tunku will accommodate them if that is the wish of the Borneo people.

    So what are the Barisan Sosialis worried about? Why do they talk about elections first? "Let us first have the three territories come in as one unit before we have a Malaysia merger." Surely, Mr Speaker, Sir, anybody knows that those proposals, if carried out, will take at least another ten years. The Member for Cairnhill says more. Probably he is right, but I say at least ten years. Can we wait for another ten years? Can Singapore wait for another ten years? Speaking for Singapore. I say we cannot wait. I do not know about the Bornean territories.

    You will recollect, Mr Speaker, Sir, when there was a Regional Conference of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association of which you were Chairman,

Column: 840

I urged upon the conference the necessity to get together quickly. That was sometime in July or August last year. I then urged upon the conference that the position of Singapore was such that it was Singapore that wished the getting together quicker than any other part of this area which is now being called Malaysia.

    So I say to Members of the Barisan Sosialis: let us look after our own interests first, and think of somebody else's afterwards. Our interests are such, economically, politically and every other way in which this Island is concerned, that the coming together with the Federation and the three Borneo territories is vital to our survival. Therefore, let us get on with it. Let the Bornean territories decide what is best' for them and let the Commission help them decide.

    Mr Speaker, it was curious that when the West Irian motion was being discussed - a matter which did not really concern the vital interests of Singapore - the P.A.P. Government, the Barisan Sosialis, the U.P.P. (who all originally started off in this House as P.A.P. Members) reached agreement on something which did not really concern Singapore. But on matters which vitally concern our existence they were fighting like cats and dogs, except for the U.P.P., of course, who agreed. But so far as the Barisan are concerned, they disagreed. I think we have reached a stage in this House where if the P.A.P. were to say something is white, the Barisan are going to say that it is black; and where the Barisan were to say it is yellow, the P.A.P. would say it is red. I think it is a great pity we have reached this stage on a motion of national importance.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, you will recollect another Barisan Sosialis Member saying, "We do not like this because this is something the P.A.P. has brought about." That is one of the reasons given. Now, is that a valid, substantial reason on a national issue such as this? It is the good fortune of the P.A.P. to be the Government of the country at a time in history when merger is becoming possible. But that is their good fortune and it is not due to them entirely.

Column: 841

It is the historical sequence of events that is bringing merger about and it is their good fortune to be at the right place at the right time.

    Therefore, I tell my friends in the Barisan Sosialis: it is not a P.A.P. merger; it is not a P.A.P. Malaysia. It is Malaysia as we all think it should be; that all these five territories should come together. We have been told how we will be accepted into the Federation. The Tunku has told the Bornean territories that he will accept them as the twelfth, thirteenth and fourteenth States, if they do not want it, Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the Commission will say so together.

    Another point they make, Sir, is a very interesting one. They say they are not Communists. They say they are not interested in a Communist form of government. They say they Want democracy. When we in Singapore talk about democracy, we talk about the parliamentary form of democracy, not guided democracy or any other type of democracy. Now, one of the arguments that the Barisan Sosialis put forward against Malaysia is this: that the Alliance Government is a Right-wing government; that the Alliance Government is a reactionary government; that the Alliance Government is this, that, and the other. If the Barisan Sosialis genuinely believe in a democratic form of government, there will always be a Right and a Left. They are all on the Left, and the Alliance is on the Right. Because the Alliance is on the Right, and the people have put them in power, therefore, they are in power rightly. It seems to me. Mr Speaker, Sir, that the Barisan are not at all against Malaysia; really speaking, they want Malaysia. It appears to me that had the Socialist Front in the Federation been in power at the moment, there would not have been this 20-day debate over these two topics in this House. So what the Barisan are really saying is that they will only agree to a Malaysia or to a coming together with the Federation only when a Left-wing government is in power in

Column: 842

the Federation. That seems to be the whole point of the attack. If they really believed in a parliamentary form of government, they should agree to what is right for this whole area, and after that convince the people that a Right-wing Government is not in the best interests of the whole area, and that it is a Left-wing government that will bring prosperity to this Island, to the Federation, and to the three Borneo territories. That is how they should do it if they were genuinely interested in a parliamentary form of democracy. But as they are not, it does appear to me that when they say, "We are democrats," they are merely giving lip service to it at the moment because they cannot do anything else now.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not wish to touch on anything else on this debate. It has gone on for three or four days now. Everything that can be said about it has been said, and I do not wish to take up any more time of the House. But I do say this: that in this debate, let us think of Singapore first, and let us think of the Federation afterwards. Let us think of the three Borneo territories next, and let us forget Indonesia.

3.08 p.m.

    Mr Ng Teng Kian (Punggol)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir from the speeches given by Members of, the House over the last week, we discover three different stands on Malaysia. These three stands are as follows. First is the stand of the P.A.P. together with the Alliance. They are in support of the Malaysia concept as planned by the Federation Government. Second is that of the Barisan Sosialis. They oppose this Malaysia concept without any principles whatsoever. They are blindly opposing this Malaysia plan as brought up and suggested by the Federation of Malaya.

    Mr Low Por Tuck (Havelock): On a point of clarification, Sir.

    Mr Ng Teng Kian resumed his seat.

    Mr Low Por Tuck: The Member for Punggol says that the Barisan Sosialis are against the concept of Malaysia. In fact, we agree to the concept of Malaysia, but it is the plan that we are against.

Column: 843



    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Make up your mind.

    Mr Ng Teng Kian(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know theories which are always their own theories. I do not want to argue with them further in this respect.

    So all the unprincipled opposition to the concept of Malaysia and the plan as proposed by the Federation Government is the second stand.

    The third stand is that of the U.P.P. together with the Workers' Party in support of the Malaysia concept but against the Malaysia plan as proposed by the Federation Government. Mr Speaker, Sir, geographically, economically, culturally, Singapore, and Malaya together with the Borneo territories belong to the same family, just the same as its peoples. The peoples have common cultures, common races and use a common currency. They have similar religions, they have a common mode of life, and their separation has been brought about as the result of colonial rule. This separation of the peoples in these five territories is a result of the divide-and-rule policy of the colonialists. By this policy, the colonialists could exploit the peoples of these five territories, and, therefore, in this pant of the world, when colonialism is dying out, we can say that the peoples of the five territories must gel together and rally under one flag to oppose their common enemy. In this way we will be able to go forward with history.

    Malaysia is the greatest producer of rubber and tin in the world. In Borneo there is a great deal of natural resources waiting for the people to tap. In Singapore we have many trained personnel and skilled workers. In addition, we have a very good port and harbour facilities. In fact, we are the fifth great port in the world. If the peoples in the five territories can unite together, then they will be able to make full use of their natural resources and their skilled labour in order to bring about a better future for the 10 million people living in this area. That is why we of the U.P.P. are in support of the Malaysia concept,
